PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (not every day, but regularly)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (neighbors would generally go to each other's homes without invitation.)

5. What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Or a Sunday afternoon?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst what happened they were held at home? Or were they held at some other place?

8. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Answer:

How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (not every day, but once or twice a week, etc.)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? (usually on Sundays)

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (usually invited when visiting, but sometimes when not visiting)

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? (usually afternoon)

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

(that is, was the term "make polluok" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

A baby of two or three months old would be considered too young to be visited.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a quilting, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were, how often they occurred, what kind of work was done, what kind of food was served, etc.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whisky drives or dances in homes? Describe. (describe, how many, how often, how long, what kind of music, etc.)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Races for men: Race for women carry an egg on a spoon who ever got there first without losing the egg wins. Also children's races: which between three women would be in the wheelbarrow race (egg) would jump but the one who got there first. Also tug of war with a rope. Also had a ball toss game with a hole in the middle. The man would stand in place look out the hole and try to throw the ball through the hole. If anyone could hit the man as he looked out, they had lost. Also had a sack race. 25 yards distance at the start. If anyone fell they had to go back to the start. 

30. What arrangements were made for eating? Was there a general arrangement families and friends form smaller groups? There being no pavilion at the time of the school, that morning families and friends formed smaller groups and sat them in the grounds & shelter over long tables we set outside the school.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? The ladies of the District Hall took tables, served cold meat, potato salad, jelly, pies & cakes. Served tea or coffee which was preferred. 25 cents charged each one for dinner.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Started about 1/2 clock in the afternoon lasted till dark till after dinner. A dance followed in the evening for those who wished to stay.
